image.altText: Two election placard - one for yes, one for no

items.synopsis: Follow our live coverage of the Voice to Parliament campaign on Wednesday, October 11.

title.children: 'There's nothing to be fearful about': Pat Dodson's Press Club message to undecided Voice voters

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Reporting by Matt Garrick The family of late Northern Territory land rights giant Yunupiŋu have voiced their sadness over comments made by Opposition Leader Peter Dutton yesterday, saying they "twisted" his legacy. The late Gumatj clan leader and former Australian of the Year passed away earlier this year at age 74. Mr Dutton was speaking at a press conference in Adelaide, where he made a link between Yunupiŋu's achievements in helping improve economic outcomes for his Yolŋu people, and how that was a reason Australia should vote against the "Canberra-based bureaucracy" of an Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Voice to Parliament. Indigenous Australians Minister Linda Burney called for Mr Dutton to apologise, accusing him of using the late leader's "name in vain" and of making inaccurate references to East Arnhem Land. Yunupiŋu's brother and now-leader of the Gumatj clan Djawa Yunupiŋu released a short statement in relation to Mr Dutton's comments, via the Yothu Yindi Foundation. "It saddens our family to see my brother's name and legacy twisted like this," Mr Yunupiŋu said. "He was a strong advocate for the Voice, and Mr Dutton knows that. "He heard the same message loud and clear when he met with the 13-clan leadership of the Dilak Council, who also support a Voice." Djawa Yunupiŋu and the Dilak Council offered their unequivocal support towards a Voice to Parliament at the Garma Festival in north-east Arnhem Land earlier this year.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Family of Yunupiŋu 'saddened' by Peter Dutton's comments

children.content: Reporting by Matt Garrick
The family of late Northern Territory land rights giant
Yunupiŋu
have voiced their sadness over comments made by
Opposition Leader Peter Dutton
yesterday, saying they "twisted" his legacy.
The late Gumatj clan leader and former Australian of the Year passed away earlier this year at age 74.

Mr Dutton was speaking at a press conference in Adelaide, where he made a link between Yunupiŋu's achievements in helping improve economic outcomes for his Yolŋu people, and how that was a reason Australia should vote against the "Canberra-based bureaucracy" of an Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Voice to Parliament.
Indigenous Australians Minister Linda Burney
called for Mr Dutton to apologise, accusing him of using the late leader's "name in vain" and of making inaccurate references to East Arnhem Land.
Yunupiŋu's brother and now-leader of the Gumatj clan
Djawa Yunupiŋu
released a short statement in relation to Mr Dutton's comments, via the Yothu Yindi Foundation.
Gumatj leader Djawa Yunupiŋu.
(ABC News: Hamish Harty)
"It saddens our family to see my brother's name and legacy twisted like this," Mr Yunupiŋu said.
"He was a strong advocate for the Voice, and Mr Dutton knows that.
"He heard the same message loud and clear when he met with the 13-clan leadership of the Dilak Council, who also support a Voice."
Djawa Yunupiŋu and the Dilak Council offered their unequivocal support towards a Voice to Parliament at the Garma Festival in north-east Arnhem Land earlier this year.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Senator Dodson was asked to explain how the Voice will fix injustices against Indigenous people. "You need to establish you were here prior to the establishment of the colonisation. "The second thing we're saying is they ought to have a say to the Parliament and the executive on matters their communities have concerns about. "There's nothing scary about that. "There's absolutely nothing scary about it. "There's nothing to be fearful about it. "If you are confused, look in mirror and say is a good thing to do that?"
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Dodson's message to the undecided 'If you are confused, look in mirror'

children.content: Senator Dodson was asked to explain how the Voice will fix injustices against Indigenous people.
"You need to establish you were here prior to the establishment of the colonisation.
"The second thing we're saying is they ought to have a say to the Parliament and the executive on matters their communities have concerns about.
"There's nothing scary about that.
"There's absolutely nothing scary about it.
"There's nothing to be fearful about it.
"If you are confused, look in mirror and say is a good thing to do that?"

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Senator Dodson said he was worried about the future of funding and support for Aboriginal nations if the No vote succeeds in the referendum. "We have this opportunity now with the referendum to change the way we relate to one another and the way governments go about their business. "If you want the government to deliver more of the same or to become more draconian, then vote No. "If you don't want them to go down that path, vote Yes."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: No vote win will lead to 'more draconian' government, says Dodson

children.content: Senator Dodson said he was worried about the future of funding and support for Aboriginal nations if the No vote succeeds in the referendum.
"We have this opportunity now with the referendum to change the way we relate to one another and the way governments go about their business.
"If you want the government to deliver more of the same or to become more draconian, then vote No.
"If you don't want them to go down that path, vote Yes."

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The federal government says it is looking at "all options" to help Australians trying to leave Israel amid the current conflict, as Transport Minister Catherine King speaks with Qantas and Virgin about flight options. There are more than 10,000 Australians living in Israel, and others who are visiting as tourists. The official advice to Australians is to book a commercial flight home, but there have been widespread cancellations across several airlines. For more, here's the story by Tom Lowrey and Stephanie Borys :
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Qantas and Virgin asked to bring Australians home from Israel

featuredLink.title: Qantas and Virgin asked to bring Australians home from Israel

children.content: The federal government says it is looking at "all options"
to help Australians trying to leave Israel amid the current conflict, as Transport Minister Catherine King speaks with Qantas and Virgin about flight options.
There are more than 10,000 Australians living in Israel, and others who are visiting as tourists.
The official advice to Australians is to book a commercial flight home, but there have been widespread cancellations across several airlines.
For more, here's the story by
Tom Lowrey
and
Stephanie Borys

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Apple and Google will soon be required to comply with rules already imposed on credit cards and EFTPOS transactions in an attempt by the federal government to better protect consumers. A growing number of Australians are using digital wallets, such as Apple and Google Pay, that are loaded on a phone to pay for goods and services. About 35 per cent of card transactions in the June quarter were made using digital wallets, compared to 10 per cent in early 2020. Figures from the Reserve Bank of Australia reveal nearly two-thirds of people aged between 18 and 29 use digital payment systems on mobile phones, and the number of people over 65 using digital wallets has also tripled since 2019. Treasurer Jim Chalmers has argued that new payment systems, like digital wallets, should be regulated in the same way as credit cards, EFTPOS and other transactions. For more, here's the story by political reporter Stephanie Borys :
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Apple and Google digital wallets to be brought under payment rules for credit cards, EFTPOS

featuredLink.title: Apple and Google's digital wallets to be brought under payment rules

children.content: Apple and Google will soon be required to comply with rules already imposed on credit cards and EFTPOS transactions in an attempt by the federal government to better protect consumers.
A growing number of Australians are using digital wallets, such as Apple and Google Pay, that are loaded on a phone to pay for goods and services.
About 35 per cent of card transactions in the June quarter were made using digital wallets, compared to 10 per cent in early 2020.

Figures from the Reserve Bank of Australia reveal nearly two-thirds of people aged between 18 and 29 use digital payment systems on mobile phones, and the number of people over 65 using digital wallets has also tripled since 2019.
Treasurer Jim Chalmers has argued that new payment systems, like digital wallets, should be regulated in the same way as credit cards, EFTPOS and other transactions.
For more, here's the story by political reporter
Stephanie Borys

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Former cryptocurrency billionaire Sam Bankman-Fried's fraud case is unfolding in New York City, with a key witness taking to the stand. Caroline Ellison, the tech executive who ran Bankman-Fried’s hedge fund while sometimes dating him, told the court he directed her to commit fraud. Her testimony could play a major role in convicting the 31-year-old, which could see him imprisoned for decades. Here's what she said in court during her testimony:

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The federal government has asked Qantas and Virgin Australia whether they could organise evacuation flights for Australians wanting to leave Israel. Earlier this week, the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade was told to start contingency planning in the event commercial flights stopped operating. The Australian government is urging the more than 10,000 Australian citizens and tourists wanting to leave the country to take commercial flights where possible. Transport Minister Catherine King has spoken to Qantas chief executive Vanessa Hudson and Virgin Australia's Jayne Hrdlicka about whether their airlines could help. Read the full story below.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Federal government asks Australian airlines to organise evacuation flights from Israel

featuredLink.title: 'All options' under consideration to get Australians out of Israel, amid calls for repatriation flights

children.content: The federal government has asked Qantas and Virgin Australia whether they could organise evacuation flights for Australians wanting to leave Israel.
Earlier this week, the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade was told to start contingency planning in the event commercial flights stopped operating.
The Australian government is urging the more than 10,000 Australian citizens and tourists wanting to leave the country to take commercial flights where possible.
Transport Minister Catherine King has spoken to Qantas chief executive Vanessa Hudson and Virgin Australia's Jayne Hrdlicka about whether their airlines could help.
Read the full story below.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: A Palestinian doctor has painted a grim picture of life in Gaza under Israeli bombardment. Khamis Elessi, who is a neuro-rehabilitation and pain medicine consultant at the Islamic University of Gaza, told ABC News Radio he felt as if he was in a scene from the Living Dead. "As I'm talking to you there are 13 people who've been brought from under the rubble of their homes without any prior warning, so the house was demolished on top of the residents," he said. Other times people were left running blindly looking for shelter after being given just minutes to evacuate. "The next morning you open your windows and you look through it and you find it's still dark — even though it's 7am or 8am — not because there is no sun but because everything is covered with a thick layer of smog and smoke and fires are still igniting in so many buildings and so many roads,” he said. “People running amongst the shrapnel, the debris … car windows broken and they are running to seek new shelter and they are crying and their faces are covered with dark black smoke, they look like they are coming from Return of the Living Dead. It's just like an action movie about zombies." Doctors used to treating people in pain are now struggling to treat shrapnel wounds, and devasting injuries from explosions. "The vast majority of injuries are children, the vast majority of dead are children and next to them is women unfortunately," he said, adding that without sufficient medicine or equipment doctors could not save them. He said hospitals were overwhelmed and not equipped to receive "2,000 patients a day" with morgues full and ice-cream refrigerators being used to store the dead.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Palestinian doctor says he feels like he is in a scene from the Living Dead

children.content: A
Palestinian
doctor has painted a grim picture of life in Gaza under Israeli bombardment.
Khamis Elessi
, who is a neuro-rehabilitation and pain medicine consultant at the Islamic University of Gaza, told ABC News Radio he felt as if he was in a scene from the Living Dead.
"As I'm talking to you there are 13 people who've been brought from under the rubble of their homes without any prior warning, so the house was demolished on top of the residents," he said.
Other times people were left running blindly looking for shelter after being given just minutes to evacuate.

"The next morning you open your windows and you look through it and you find it's still dark — even though it's 7am or 8am — not because there is no sun but because everything is covered with a thick layer of smog and smoke and fires are still igniting in so many buildings and so many roads,” he said.

“People running amongst the shrapnel, the debris … car windows broken and they are running to seek new shelter and they are crying and their faces are covered with dark black smoke, they look like they are coming from Return of the Living Dead. It's just like an action movie about zombies."
Palestinian doctor Khamis Elessi.
(Supplied)
Doctors used to treating people in pain are now struggling to treat shrapnel wounds, and devasting injuries from explosions.

"The vast majority of injuries are children, the vast majority of dead are children and next to them is women unfortunately," he said, adding that without sufficient medicine or equipment doctors could not save them.
He said hospitals were overwhelmed and not equipped to receive "2,000 patients a day" with morgues full and ice-cream refrigerators being used to store the dead.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Essendon list manager Adrian Dodoro is on Trade Radio as we speak talking about Gresham, Duursma and a bit more. He says the Bombers will submit paperwork for Jade Gresham within the next 24 hours, but he hasn't spoken to St Kilda yet to learn of their plans regarding potentially matching the bid. Dodoro also says the Duursma and Zerk-Thatcher deals "logically go hand in hand". He says it is early days and discussions with Port Adelaide will continue over the next few days. Dodoro says Brad Scott played a big part in convincing Duursma to seek a move to Essendon.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Adrian Dodoro opens up on the Bombers' situation

children.content: (Getty Images)
Essendon list manager Adrian Dodoro is on Trade Radio as we speak talking about Gresham, Duursma and a bit more.
He says the Bombers will submit paperwork for Jade Gresham within the next 24 hours, but he hasn't spoken to St Kilda yet to learn of their plans regarding potentially matching the bid.
Dodoro also says the Duursma and Zerk-Thatcher deals "logically go hand in hand". He says it is early days and discussions with Port Adelaide will continue over the next few days.
Dodoro says Brad Scott played a big part in convincing Duursma to seek a move to Essendon.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: SEN, AFL.com.au and The Age are reporting the deal has been struck, with the clubs and league soon to confirm it. Sydney have traded Dylan Stephens and pick 25 to North Melbourne for pick 44 and a future end-of-first-round pick. Interesting to see that pick 25 on the move. The Grundy/Adams picture shifts yet again. I would imagine that selection will soon be sent to Carlton to get Zac Fisher to North as well. UPDATE : The AFL has now confirmed the deal.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Dylan Stephens has been traded to North Melbourne

children.content: (Getty Images)
SEN, AFL.com.au and The Age are reporting the deal has been struck, with the clubs and league soon to confirm it.
Sydney have traded Dylan Stephens and pick 25 to North Melbourne for pick 44 and a future end-of-first-round pick.
Interesting to see that pick 25 on the move. The Grundy/Adams picture shifts yet again.
I would imagine that selection will soon be sent to Carlton to get Zac Fisher to North as well.
UPDATE
: The AFL has now confirmed the deal.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The latest in our look at the 2023 draft class is an exciting player with a familiar name, who has rocketed up into top three calculations in recent months. Zane Duursma is a hybrid forward, tall and strong in the air and on the lead but just as deadly when the ball hits the deck. Duursma is an intelligent and skilful player who can also work his defenders over with his impressive tank. Duursma kicked a mountain of goals this year for both Vic Country and the Gippsland Power, and by the end of the season was probably the hottest player in the Coates League. He can float in and out of games, but can be absolutely devastating with only a handful of touches. He's also flagged an interest in moving into the midfield later in his career, but for the first few years at least Duursma will be a dangerous half-forward, a tough match-up for the opposition due to his wide range of abilities. The top five in this year's draft looms large for clubs on the look out for a touch of class.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Draft Spotlight — Zane Duursma

children.content: (Getty Images)
The latest in our look at the 2023 draft class is an exciting player with a familiar name, who has rocketed up into top three calculations in recent months.

Zane Duursma is a hybrid forward, tall and strong in the air and on the lead but just as deadly when the ball hits the deck. Duursma is an intelligent and skilful player who can also work his defenders over with his impressive tank.

Duursma kicked a mountain of goals this year for both Vic Country and the Gippsland Power, and by the end of the season was probably the hottest player in the Coates League. He can float in and out of games, but can be absolutely devastating with only a handful of touches.
(Getty Images)

He's also flagged an interest in moving into the midfield later in his career, but for the first few years at least Duursma will be a dangerous half-forward, a tough match-up for the opposition due to his wide range of abilities.
The top five in this year's draft looms large for clubs on the look out for a touch of class.
